title: RL31823
content: In January 2004, federal white-collar employees received a 1.5% annual pay adjustment and a 0.5% locality-based comparability payment under Executive Order 13322. A larger pay adjustment of 4.1% for 2004 was included in the Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004. H.R. 2673 provided a 4.1% pay adjustment to federal civilian employees, which was signed into law on January 23, 2004, and included an additional 2.1% pay adjustment. The President issued Executive Order 13332 on March 3, 2004, providing an additional pay adjustment for federal civilian employees. The adjustment included an average 1.2% annual and 0.9% locality increase. OPM published revised salary tables for 2004 on March 4, 2004. Federal white-collar employees receive an annual pay adjustment and locality-based comparability payment under FEPCA. The adjustments are not based on cost-of-living measures. In 2003, federal white-collar employees received a 4.1% combined annual and locality pay adjustment. The nationwide average net pay increase would have been 18.56% if specified by FEPCA. In 2004, they also received a 4.1% adjustment, with a potential net pay increase of 15.15% if specified by FEPCA. This report focuses on the January 2004 annual adjustment and locality payments for federal employees under various schedules. The President may adjust salaries of administrative law judges annually. SL and ST positions may receive the adjustment at agency heads' discretion. Contract appeals board members' adjustments depend on Executive Schedule pay. The adjustment is based on the Employment Cost Index (ECI), with a 2.7% across-the-board pay adjustment in January 2004. The pay adjustment is effective at the start of the first pay period after January 1 each year. The President can issue an alternative plan if needed. FEPCA allows the President to issue an alternative plan for salary adjustments, with President Bush implementing a 1.5% pay adjustment in January 2004. GS employees receive locality-based comparability payments, which may also extend to other positions. OPM clarified limitations for non-General Schedule employees in December 2001. Blue-collar workers under the Federal Wage System receive a prevailing rate adjustment capped at the average pay adjustment for white-collar employees. In 2004, blue-collar pay adjustments will not be less than GS employees in the same location. Special rate employees receive the higher of special rate or locality payment. Law enforcement officers get both special rates and locality pay. Employees in Alaska, Hawaii, and outside the US receive a cost-of-living allowance instead of locality pay. FEPCA established locality-based comparability payments for GS employees to address pay disparities greater than 5%. The President can adjust payments in case of national emergency or economic conditions. President Bush issued a plan for a 0.5% locality pay adjustment in January 2004. President Bush issued an alternative plan on August 27, 2003, for a 0.5% locality pay adjustment in January 2004. Executive Order 13322, issued on December 30, 2003, implemented the plan. The Bureau of Labor Statistics conducts surveys to document non-federal pay rates in 32 pay areas nationwide. The surveys transitioned from the Occupational Compensation Survey Program to the National Compensation Survey program, with a phase-in of NCS survey data approved for the January 2004 locality payments. Survey results are submitted to OPM for comparison of federal and non-federal salaries by grade in each pay area. The Federal Employees Pay Comparability Act (FEPCA) aims to reduce the pay gap between federal and non-federal salaries to 5%. Each year, OPM adjusts the overall average percentage pay gap for each pay area to meet this target. FEPCA also mandates the closure of a certain percentage of the gap each year, starting at 20% in 1994 and increasing annually. However, the actual closure of the gap has been lower than the mandated percentages, with gradual progress made over the years. The pay gap reduction under FEPCA has been slow but steady, with percentages closing each year from 23.5% in 1995 to 44% in 2003. Locality rates are determined based on the target gap of 5%, using data from OCSP and NCS surveys. The Federal Salary Council explained how pay gaps for January 2004 locality payments were determined using aged BLS survey data from various pay areas ranging from 1995 to 1996. The data was adjusted to a common reference date of March 2002 before comparing it to GS pay data. The Federal Salary Council reported a 32.02% gap between GS average salaries and non-federal average salaries in March 2002. To reduce this disparity to 5%, an average increase of 25.73% was recommended for 2004. Locality pay raises ranging from 19.45% to 47.64% were suggested, with Washington, DC at 28.78%. The council suggested improvements to the BLS National Compensation Survey program in their report to the Pay Agent. The council's memorandum to the Pay Agent on the 2004 locality payments provided a progress report on improvements to the BLS National Compensation Survey program. OPM and BLS have developed new evaluation systems and models to estimate missing data, improve job matching, and provide grade level guides for occupational families. Additional improvements are anticipated in the future. BLS and Pay Agent staff have designed a new approach for grading supervisory occupations based on the highest level of work supervised. Final tests of the new approach are to be conducted in the fall, with hopes of implementation in surveys by December 2003. BLS has also developed methods to identify and exclude jobs classified above GS-15 in government, with these data excluded from the Pay Agent this year. It also suggested that additional resources should be committed by BLS to increase sample size in localities with significant pay gaps. The definition of metropolitan areas for locality pay areas changed automatically with OMB revisions, but final regulations in 2003 stated that changes would no longer occur automatically. On April 22, 2003, OPM published final regulations stating that locality pay areas no longer change automatically with new definitions of metropolitan areas. OMB revised definitions for Metropolitan Statistical Areas on June 6, 2003, based on new criteria and 2000 census data. OPM modified GS locality pay regulations to align with former OMB statistical area definitions for review by the Federal Salary Council and the President's Pay Agent in 2003. Major changes considered included differences in statistical area definitions and the concept of 'Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Areas'. The concept of 'Consolidated Metropolitan Statistical Areas' used in defining locality pay areas has changed. New concepts like 'Micropolitan Statistical Areas' and 'Combined Statistical Areas' have been introduced. Population density is no longer a criterion, and commuting thresholds have been adjusted. A Federal Salary Council working group recommended considering the new definitions for the locality pay program, with further study needed before any decisions are made. The Federal Salary Council working group recommended adopting new MSA definitions for locality pay areas, acknowledging changes in demographics and criteria. They also suggested using Combined Statistical Areas for pay adjustments in January 2005, revising pay area definitions, and folding three current pay areas into RUS. Further study is needed before any decisions are made. The Federal Salary Council working group recommended adopting new MSA definitions for locality pay areas, suggesting revisions to pay area definitions and folding three current pay areas into RUS to save resources for surveying other areas. The council's recommendations were tentatively approved by the Pay Agent and the President for January 2005 pay adjustments. In 2004, OPM will publish proposed changes on locality pay in the Federal Register for public comments. An amendment to H.R. 2989 was agreed upon by the House of Representatives, stating that funds cannot be used to disestablish any pay locality. During the markup of the bill, an amendment was proposed by Representative Sam Farr regarding the reduction in pay for federal employees in Monterey County, California. Senator Jack Reed offered a similar amendment that was agreed to by the Senate, preventing the removal of any area from coverage under a locality pay area. This amendment was incorporated into the Consolidated Appropriations Act. The Consolidated Appropriations Act for FY2004 included an amendment preventing the removal of any area from coverage under a locality pay area. This provision was enacted as Section 644 of P.L. 108-199 on January 23, 2004. The Pay Agent submitted its annual report to the President on the 2004 locality payments on December 5, 2002, recommending against allowing the locality pay increases to take effect in January 2004 due to the national emergency situation and economic slowdown. The Pay Agent recommended against allowing locality pay increases in January 2004 due to economic concerns and suggested alternative compensation approaches for Federal employees. The cost of the proposed locality-based payments would be $8.830 billion to reduce pay disparity. The Pay Agent did not adopt the council's recommendation to include Barnstable County, Massachusetts, in the Boston locality pay area for January 2004. The Pay Agent looks forward to reviewing the results of the NCS data delivered next year and mentioned that the last two improvements in NCS surveys will begin to affect data delivered in 2005. The Pay Agent encouraged expedited completion of improvements in NCS surveys for data delivery in 2005. The Federal Salary Council and Pay Agent recommendations for the January 2005 pay adjustments are discussed in CRS Report RL32355, Federal White-Collar Pay: FY2005 Salary Adjustments. FEPCA aims to reduce the disparity between non-federal and federal salaries to 5%. However, only a small percentage of the target pay gaps has been closed each year, leading to a continued pay disparity. The Federal Salary Council and the Pay Agent report that the pay disparity between non-federal and federal salaries averages 25.73% for 2004. Concerns have been raised about the flawed methodology for setting federal pay adjustments since FEPCA's enactment in 1993. Despite these concerns, no proposals were made to change FEPCA, and the methodology remains a concern due to issues with data completeness and credibility. Bureau of Labor Statistics surveys documenting non-federal rates of pay were not approved for use in determining locality payments for several years, leading to the use of aged survey data. In 2001, Congress directed the President's Pay Agent to address concerns with the methodology for setting federal pay adjustments. The Pay Agent reported to Congress in 2001 and highlighted methodological concerns. Improvements to the survey methodology were discussed, and in 2002, the Congressional Budget Office compared federal General Schedule employee salaries with nonfederal employees in similar jobs. The Congressional Budget Office compared federal General Schedule employee salaries with nonfederal employees in similar jobs. The comparison showed that federal employees in professional and administrative occupations tended to earn less than their private sector counterparts, with about 85 percent lagging behind by more than 20 percent. In contrast, about 30 percent of federal employees in technical and clerical occupations had salaries higher than those in the private sector. The analysis revealed a concern that the federal pay system does not allow for variation in pay raises by occupation, potentially leading to smaller pay raises for employees in certain occupations. The Congressional Budget Office found that federal employees in professional and administrative occupations earn less than their private sector counterparts, while those in technical and clerical occupations earn more. The current federal pay system fails to provide comparable pay to nonfederal jobs, with some occupational groups receiving above-market salaries and others below-market salaries. Implementing the Federal Employees Pay Comparability Act (FEPCA) fully would not address the pay disparity issue, especially as the cost of locality-based comparability payments is a concern. Pay Agent estimated that the January 2004 locality-based comparability payments would cost $8.830 billion to reduce the pay disparity to 5% as required by FEPCA.
